text:
RT @alanfeuer: Do not forget. 
Even as the protests continue and the virus slowly spreads, the US attorney's office in Manhattan is still embroiled in a nasty trans-Atlantic spat with Prince Andrew, Duke of York, over the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

text:
RT @tminsberg: Many women's pro sports leagues follow a model dubbed "pink it and shrink it" (really.)

name: nytimes
text: Daniel Radcliffe, the lead actor in the “Harry Potter” films, criticized J.K Rowling’s comments on gender identity. "Transgender women are women. Any statement to the contrary erases the identity and dignity of transgender people," he wrote. https://t.co/uZbJCk2NjK

name: nytimes
text:
Bail was set on Monday at up to $1.25 million for Derek Chauvin, the white former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in the killing of George Floyd. 

Live updates about nationwide protests: https://t.co/TMfechTK2o

name: nytimes
text: “For the last 3 years, we’ve all had this debate about statues in Britain,” said a columnist for The Guardian. “It feels as if now there is not even a debate — people are just acting. That is inspired by the movement we’re seeing in America.” https://t.co/dRzFA1xNPI

name: nytimes
text:
RT @ByMikeBaker: Persistent protests in the Northwest are forcing concessions.

Today, the Portland police chief stepped down and Seattle police abandoned their East Precinct.

Tonight, Portland protesters shut down I-84 and Seattle ones have created their own barricades.

https://t.co/bubBGX6hzx

name: nytimes
text: One year ago on June 9, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in Hong Kong gathered for a march that became the start of the city’s biggest political crisis in decades https://t.co/A62pNy1CfK https://t.co/2hlVSx9Djn

name: nytimes
text: In the months that followed, street clashes between black-clad protesters and the police became routine. Demonstrators broke into the local legislature, staged sit-ins at the airport, and turned a university campus into a fiery battleground. https://t.co/1sjIFPIKbw https://t.co/7fdO3kpDqj

name: nytimes
text: The protests eased this year because of the coronavirus pandemic. But they are re-emerging. Thousands of people defied the authorities last week and gathered in districts across Hong Kong to mark the anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. https://t.co/6HyA8HkfyV https://t.co/fhdiEYRnym

name: nytimes
text: Europe morning briefing: Here's what you need to know to start your day https://t.co/eLLmsguejQ

text: RT @gillianwong: One year ago today, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in Hong Kong gathered for a march that became the start of the semiautonomous Chinese city’s biggest political crisis in decades. By @austinramzy @mikeives  https://t.co/UKm6UC5Z2x

name: nytimes
text:
RT @MujMash: For decades, Afghans tuned their radios to “Radio Afghanistan” twice a day to hear the names of the newly dead — 

اعلانات فوتی

These days, it’s not that people are not dying — it is that the program, and the radio itself, are fading.

@jimhuylebroek

https://t.co/id5Vj2Ep1J

name: nytimes
text: North Korea said on Tuesday that it would cut off all communication lines with South Korea, including military hotlines, as it vowed to start treating the South as an “enemy” https://t.co/v8bbm1IZFs

name: nytimes
text: Iran passed a law making it a crime to emotionally or physically abuse or abandon a child, the nation’s first legal protection for children. The brutal killing of a 14-year-old girl by her father last month had led to nationwide outrage. https://t.co/A6SogJskLs

name: nytimes
text: Demonstrators dumped a statue of the 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston into Bristol Harbor. Now the protesters are turning their sights on statues of Cecil Rhodes, an even more potent symbol of Britain’s racist colonial past. https://t.co/5IWkjnM60d

name: nytimes
text: Through decades of coups, invasions and endless war, Afghans tuned to Radio Afghanistan twice a day to hear the names of the newly dead. Now, that all seems gone. It is not that people are not dying — it is that the program, and the radio itself, are. https://t.co/X8WiGwOAqy

name: nytimes
text: Of the roughly 4,600 Twitter accounts that reposted China’s leading envoys and state-run news outlets recently, many acted suspiciously, The New York Times found. Many accounts behaved with a single-mindedness that could suggest a coordinated campaign. https://t.co/NI2cW4jzJr

name: nytimes
text: “Bacteria are — and always have been — the dominant forms of life on Earth," wrote Stephen Jay Gould. This is the story of one of the world's most comprehensive libraries of those bacteria. https://t.co/BkNwBhUkEM

name: nytimes
text: Prince Andrew’s lawyers said that he had agreed 3 times to aid New York prosecutors in their investigation into allegations of crimes by Jeffrey Epstein and his associates. A top federal prosecutor effectively called the prince a liar. https://t.co/Vsfh0avcn3

name: nytimes
text: The German soccer team Saarbrücken knocked off a string of bigger, better teams to reach a cup semifinal. Its biggest obstacle now is not just another top-tier opponent. It's that it hasn't played a game in 3 months. https://t.co/GWWJAI0hk3

name: nytimes
text: A Texas inmate who spent nearly 40 years on death row was granted parole on Monday. Bobby Moore, 60, had been the center of a landmark case in which the U.S. Supreme Court overturned his death sentence because he is intellectually disabled. https://t.co/yFViPgOoW1
